Making cheese

Source: vignettes/cheese.Rmd
cheese.Rmd

Being able to structure code that can get to presentation-ready results in an automated way, and is robust to updates in the data, changes in methodological specfications, etc. can not only be a huge time saver, but also help mitigate errors from tedious tasks. The cheese package was designed with this philosophy in mind, providing tools for working with data and results during statistical analysis.

The dataset used throughout the tutorial comes from the UCI Machine Learning Repository.

#Load the package
require(cheese)
## Loading required package: cheese
#Look at the data
heart_disease
## # A tibble: 303 x 9
##      Age Sex   ChestPain    BP Cholesterol BloodSugar MaximumHR
##    <dbl> <fct> <fct>     <dbl>       <dbl> <lgl>          <dbl>
##  1    63 Male  Typical …   145         233 TRUE             150
##  2    67 Male  Asymptom…   160         286 FALSE            108

Details of the pre-processing steps of the raw data to what is found within the package can be found on the package’s Github site here.

Summarizing data

heart_disease %>%
  univariate_table()
Variable Level Summary
Age 56 (48, 61)
Sex Female 97 (32.01%)
Male 206 (67.99%)
ChestPain Typical angina 23 (7.59%)
Atypical angina 50 (16.5%)
Non-anginal pain 86 (28.38%)
Asymptomatic 144 (47.52%)
BP 130 (120, 140)
Cholesterol 241 (211, 275)
MaximumHR 153 (133.5, 166)
ExerciseInducedAngina No 204 (67.33%)
Yes 99 (32.67%)
HeartDisease No 164 (54.13%)
Yes 139 (45.87%) 
heart_disease %>%
  univariate_table(
    strata = ~ Sex,
    add_n = TRUE
  )
Variable Level Female (N=97) Male (N=206)
Age 57 (50, 63) 54.5 (47, 59.75)
